entry.title: Combined summary - OP_CHECKSPVPROOFVERIFY
entry.summary: The article discusses how to incentivize nodes to construct SPV proofs, noting that the major issue with Bitcoin is how to incentivize nodes to do so. The author suggests outsourcing SPV proofs from other nodes using the Lightning Network (LN) as a practical solution. They propose including SPV proofs in the blockchain when the SPV client fails to pay the prover. Eric Lombrozo suggested that it might be possible to outsource SPV proofs from other nodes using the LN and OP_CHECKSPVPROOFVERIFY opcode. In a discussion thread, Eric Lombrozo seeks clarification on the use of OP_CAT. The author presents two parties, Prover and Verifier, with an open channel of 10 currency units each, where the Verifier wants to pay the Prover one currency unit for an SPV proof. They create commitment transactions with different signatures, timeouts, and revocation possibilities. A script for [ProverSig + VerifierRevocation || ProverSig + SPV proof || VerifierSig + timeout] is introduced, which uses OP_IF and OP_ELSE statements. It checks if the hash of the public key equals a given value, then verifies the signature.Eric Lombrozo raises concerns over incentivizing nodes to construct SPV proofs, noting that the issue can be partially solved through P2SH, but there are still obstacles. For example, OP_CAT is currently disabled, and the txlen limit may pose problems. In an email exchange with Joseph Poon, Lombrozo suggested that with the LN, it might be possible to outsource SPV proofs from other nodes. In another email conversation between Rusty Russell and Eric Lombrozo, Eric expressed confusion over how to use OP_CAT, which Rusty suggested could be used to open-code a merkle tree calculation along with OP_HASH256.
